title: Clustering of unknown subpopulations in admixture models
text: now detail steps algorithm. Initialization: create first cluster filled, .e. c=1c = 1. convention, S0=∅S_0=\emptyset. Select $\{x,y\}={\rm argmin}\{d_n(,j); \neq j \S \setminus \bigcup_{k=1}^c S_{k-1}\}$. Test H0H_0 xx yy. S\⋃k=1cSk=∅S\setminus \bigcup_{k=1}^c S_k = \emptyset
code: If $H_0$ is not rejected then $S_1 = \{x,y\}$,\\ Else $S_1 = \{x\}$, $S_{c+1} = \{y\}$ and then $c=c+1$. Select $u={\rm argmin}\{d(i,j); i\in S_c, j\in S\setminus \bigcup_{k=1}^c S_k\}$; Test $H_0$ the simultaneous equality of all the $f_j$, $j\in S_c$ :\\   If $H_0$ not rejected, then put $S_c=S_c\bigcup \{u\}$;\\   Else $S_{c+1} = \{u\}$ and $c = c+1$.

title: Clustering of unknown subpopulations in admixture models
text: present case study 5 populations cluster ℝ+\mathbb{R}^+, Gamma-Exponential, Exponential-Exponential Gamma-Gamma mixtures.
code: ## Simulate mixture data: mixt1 <- twoComp_mixt(n = 6000, weight = 0.8,                       comp.dist = list("gamma", "exp"),                       comp.param = list(list("shape" = 16, "scale" = 1/4),                                         list("rate" = 1/3.5))) mixt2 <- twoComp_mixt(n = 6000, weight = 0.7,                       comp.dist = list("gamma", "exp"),                       comp.param = list(list("shape" = 14, "scale" = 1/2),                                         list("rate" = 1/5))) mixt3 <- twoComp_mixt(n = 6000, weight = 0.6,                       comp.dist = list("gamma", "gamma"),                       comp.param = list(list("shape" = 16, "scale" = 1/4),                                         list("shape" = 12, "scale" = 1/2))) mixt4 <- twoComp_mixt(n = 6000, weight = 0.5,                       comp.dist = list("exp", "exp"),                       comp.param = list(list("rate" = 1/2),                                         list("rate" = 1/7))) mixt5 <- twoComp_mixt(n = 6000, weight = 0.5,                       comp.dist = list("gamma", "exp"),                       comp.param = list(list("shape" = 14, "scale" = 1/2),                                         list("rate" = 1/6))) data1 <- getmixtData(mixt1) data2 <- getmixtData(mixt2) data3 <- getmixtData(mixt3) data4 <- getmixtData(mixt4) data5 <- getmixtData(mixt5) admixMod1 <- admix_model(knownComp_dist = mixt1$comp.dist[[2]],                          knownComp_param = mixt1$comp.param[[2]]) admixMod2 <- admix_model(knownComp_dist = mixt2$comp.dist[[2]],                          knownComp_param = mixt2$comp.param[[2]]) admixMod3 <- admix_model(knownComp_dist = mixt3$comp.dist[[2]],                          knownComp_param = mixt3$comp.param[[2]]) admixMod4 <- admix_model(knownComp_dist = mixt4$comp.dist[[2]],                          knownComp_param = mixt4$comp.param[[2]]) admixMod5 <- admix_model(knownComp_dist = mixt5$comp.dist[[2]],                          knownComp_param = mixt5$comp.param[[2]]) ## Look for the clusters: admix_cluster(samples = list(data1,data2,data3,data4,data5),                admixMod = list(admixMod1,admixMod2,admixMod3,admixMod4,admixMod5),               conf_level = 0.95, tune_penalty = TRUE, tabul_dist = NULL, echo = FALSE,               n_sim_tab = 50, parallel = FALSE, n_cpu = 2) #> Call: #> admix_cluster(samples = list(data1, data2, data3, data4, data5),  #>     admixMod = list(admixMod1, admixMod2, admixMod3, admixMod4,  #>         admixMod5), conf_level = 0.95, tune_penalty = TRUE, tabul_dist = NULL,  #>     echo = FALSE, n_sim_tab = 50, parallel = FALSE, n_cpu = 2) #>  #> Number of detected clusters across the samples provided: 3. #>  #> List of samples involved in each built cluster (inside c()) : #>   - Cluster #1: samples c(2, 5) #>   - Cluster #2: samples 4 #>   - Cluster #3: samples c(1, 3)

what: Estimation of the unknown component weight in an admixture model
title: Estimation of unknown elements in admixture models
text: mixture weight pp unknown component distribution can estimated using diverse techniques depending assumptions made unknown cdf FF, among ones discussed sequel: estimator provided Bordes Vandekerkhove, see (L. Bordes Vandekerkhove 2010); estimator provided Patra Sen, see (Patra Sen 2016); estimator provided Inversion - Best Matching method, see (Milhaud et al. 2024). estimation methods can performed using one single generic function estimation appropriate arguments, -called admix_estimadmix\_estim function.

previous_headings: Estimation of the unknown component weight in an admixture model
title: Estimation of unknown elements in admixture models
text: Many works studied estimation unknown proportion two-component admixture models. Among , seminal papers (Laurent Bordes, Delmas, Vandekerkhove 2006) (S. Bordes L. Mottelet Vandekerkhove 2006). papers closely connected paper (L. Bordes Vandekerkhove 2010), asymptotic normal estimator provided unknown component weight.

previous_headings: Estimation of the unknown component weight in an admixture model > The one-sample case
title: Estimation of unknown elements in admixture models
text: case, use Bordes Vandekerkhove estimator, see (L. Bordes Vandekerkhove 2010). estimation method relies symmetry unknown component density, estimator provides estimated mixing weight unknown component distribution estimated location shift parameter.
code: ## Simulate mixture data: mixt1 <- twoComp_mixt(n = 400, weight = 0.7,                       comp.dist = list("norm", "norm"),                       comp.param = list(c("mean" = 3, "sd" = 0.5),                                         c("mean" = 0, "sd" = 1))) data1 <- getmixtData(mixt1) ## Define the admixture model: admixMod <- admix_model(knownComp_dist = mixt1$comp.dist[[2]],                         knownComp_param = mixt1$comp.param[[2]]) admix_estim(samples = list(data1), admixMod = list(admixMod), est_method = 'BVdk') #> Call: #> admix_estim(samples = list(data1), admixMod = list(admixMod),  #>     est_method = "BVdk") #>  #> Estimated weight of the unknown distribution in Sample 1: 0.67 #> Estimated location of the unknown distribution in Sample 1: 2.98

title: Estimation of unknown elements in admixture models
text: full generality (assumptions made unknown component distribution), use Patra Sen estimator, see (Patra Sen 2016). case, estimated parameter mixing proportion related unknown component distribution.
code: admix_estim(samples = list(data1), admixMod = list(admixMod), est_method = 'PS') #> Call: #> admix_estim(samples = list(data1), admixMod = list(admixMod),  #>     est_method = "PS") #>  #> Estimated weight of the unknown distribution in Sample 1: 0.64

text: two-sample setting, one idea use Inversion - Best Matching (IBM) approach. IBM method ensures asymptotically normal estimators unknown quantities, useful testing perspective. However, important note estimators mostly biased F1≠F2F_1 \neq F_2, general one-sample estimation strategies (Patra Sen 2016) (L. Bordes Vandekerkhove 2010) may preferred estimate unknown component proportion general settings (despite time-consuming). latter case, one performs twice estimation method, two samples study.

title: Estimation of unknown elements in admixture models
text: null, Milhaud et al. (2024) show estimators consistent towards true parameter values. Indeed, one can see two unknown proportions consistently estimated.
code: ## Simulate mixture data: mixt1 <- twoComp_mixt(n = 450, weight = 0.4,                       comp.dist = list("norm", "norm"),                       comp.param = list(list("mean" = -2, "sd" = 0.5),                                         list("mean" = 0, "sd" = 1))) mixt2 <- twoComp_mixt(n = 380, weight = 0.7,                       comp.dist = list("norm", "norm"),                       comp.param = list(list("mean" = -2, "sd" = 0.5),                                         list("mean" = 1, "sd" = 1))) data1 <- getmixtData(mixt1) data2 <- getmixtData(mixt2) ## Define the admixture models: admixMod1 <- admix_model(knownComp_dist = mixt1$comp.dist[[2]],                          knownComp_param = mixt1$comp.param[[2]]) admixMod2 <- admix_model(knownComp_dist = mixt2$comp.dist[[2]],                          knownComp_param = mixt2$comp.param[[2]]) admix_estim(samples = list(data1, data2), admixMod = list(admixMod1, admixMod2),             est_method = 'IBM') #> Call: #> admix_estim(samples = list(data1, data2), admixMod = list(admixMod1,  #>     admixMod2), est_method = "IBM") #>  #> Pairwise estimation performed (IBM estimation method).  #> N.B.: estimated weights are reliable only if the unknown #> component distributions have previously been tested equal. #> See ?admix_test.  #>  #> ----- Pair 1 and 2 ----- #> Estimated weight of the unknown distribution in Sample 1: 0.41 #> Estimated weight of the unknown distribution in Sample 2: 0.73

previous_headings: Estimation of the unknown component weight in an admixture model > The two-sample case
what: Under the alternative hypothesis H1:F1≠F2H_1: F_1 \neq F_2
title: Estimation of unknown elements in admixture models
text: Estimators also consistent H1H_1, although can (strongly) biased compared true values illustrated following example. framework, therefore better use estimator (Patra Sen 2016), shows better performance:
code: ## Simulate mixture data: mixt1 <- twoComp_mixt(n = 800, weight = 0.5,                       comp.dist = list("norm", "norm"),                       comp.param = list(list("mean" = 1, "sd" = 0.5),                                         list("mean" = 0, "sd" = 1))) mixt2 <- twoComp_mixt(n = 600, weight = 0.7,                       comp.dist = list("norm", "norm"),                       comp.param = list(list("mean" = 3, "sd" = 0.5),                                         list("mean" = 5, "sd" = 2))) data1 <- getmixtData(mixt1) data2 <- getmixtData(mixt2) ## Define the admixture models: admixMod1 <- admix_model(knownComp_dist = mixt1$comp.dist[[2]],                          knownComp_param = mixt1$comp.param[[2]]) admixMod2 <- admix_model(knownComp_dist = mixt2$comp.dist[[2]],                          knownComp_param = mixt2$comp.param[[2]]) ## Estimate the mixture weights of the two admixture models (provide only hat(theta)_n): admix_estim(samples = list(data1, data2), admixMod = list(admixMod1, admixMod2),             est_method = 'IBM') #> Call: #> admix_estim(samples = list(data1, data2), admixMod = list(admixMod1,  #>     admixMod2), est_method = "IBM") #>  #> Pairwise estimation performed (IBM estimation method).  #> N.B.: estimated weights are reliable only if the unknown #> component distributions have previously been tested equal. #> See ?admix_test.  #>  #> ----- Pair 1 and 2 ----- #> Estimated weight of the unknown distribution in Sample 1: 0.33 #> Estimated weight of the unknown distribution in Sample 2: 0.65 admix_estim(samples = list(data1, data2), admixMod = list(admixMod1, admixMod2),             est_method = 'PS') #> Call: #> admix_estim(samples = list(data1, data2), admixMod = list(admixMod1,  #>     admixMod2), est_method = "PS") #>  #> Estimated weight of the unknown distribution in Sample 1: 0.45 #> Estimated weight of the unknown distribution in Sample 2: 0.73

what: Estimation of the unknown cumulative distribution function
title: Estimation of unknown elements in admixture models
text: Concerning unknown cdf FF, one usually estimate thanks inversion formula F(x)=L(x)−(1−p)G(x)p,F(x) = \dfrac{L(x) - (1-p)G(x)}{p}, pp consistenly estimated. commonly called decontaminated density unknown component. following, propose compare two decontaminated densities obtained unknown quantities consistently estimated IBM approach. Note null (F1=F2F_1=F_2), thus decontaminated densities look similar.
code: ## Simulate mixture data: mixt1 <- twoComp_mixt(n = 800, weight = 0.4,                       comp.dist = list("norm", "norm"),                       comp.param = list(list("mean" = 3, "sd" = 0.5),                                         list("mean" = 0, "sd" = 1))) mixt2 <- twoComp_mixt(n = 700, weight = 0.6,                       comp.dist = list("norm", "norm"),                       comp.param = list(list("mean" = 3, "sd" = 0.5),                                         list("mean" = 5, "sd" = 2))) data1 <- getmixtData(mixt1) data2 <- getmixtData(mixt2) ## Define the admixture models: admixMod1 <- admix_model(knownComp_dist = mixt1$comp.dist[[2]],                          knownComp_param = mixt1$comp.param[[2]]) admixMod2 <- admix_model(knownComp_dist = mixt2$comp.dist[[2]],                          knownComp_param = mixt2$comp.param[[2]]) ## Estimation: est <- admix_estim(samples = list(data1,data2), admixMod = list(admixMod1,admixMod2),                    est_method = 'PS') prop <- getmixingWeight(est) ## Determine the decontaminated version of the unknown density by inversion: res1 <- decontaminated_density(sample1 = data1, estim.p = prop[1], admixMod = admixMod1) res2 <- decontaminated_density(sample1 = data2, estim.p = prop[2], admixMod = admixMod2) ## Use appropriate sequence of x values: plot(x = res1, x_val = seq(from = 0, to = 6, length.out = 100), add_plot = FALSE) plot(x = res2, x_val = seq(from = 0, to = 6, length.out = 100), add_plot = TRUE, col = "red")

code: mixt1 <- twoComp_mixt(n = 450, weight = 0.4,                       comp.dist = list("norm", "norm"),                       comp.param = list(c("mean" = -2, "sd" = 0.5),                                         c("mean" = 0, "sd" = 1))) mixt2 <- twoComp_mixt(n = 600, weight = 0.24,                       comp.dist = list("norm", "norm"),                       comp.param = list(c("mean" = -2, "sd" = 0.5),                                         c("mean" = -1, "sd" = 1))) mixt3 <- twoComp_mixt(n = 400, weight = 0.53,                       comp.dist = list("norm", "norm"),                       comp.param = list(c("mean" = -2, "sd" = 0.5),                                         c("mean" = 2, "sd" = 1))) data1 <- getmixtData(mixt1) data2 <- getmixtData(mixt2) data3 <- getmixtData(mixt3) admixMod1 <- admix_model(knownComp_dist = mixt1$comp.dist[[2]],                          knownComp_param = mixt1$comp.param[[2]]) admixMod2 <- admix_model(knownComp_dist = mixt2$comp.dist[[2]],                          knownComp_param = mixt2$comp.param[[2]]) admixMod3 <- admix_model(knownComp_dist = mixt3$comp.dist[[2]],                          knownComp_param = mixt3$comp.param[[2]]) admix_test(samples = list(data1, data2, data3),             admixMod = list(admixMod1, admixMod2, admixMod3),             conf_level = 0.95, test_method = "icv", n_sim_tab = 4,             tune_penalty = FALSE, parallel = FALSE, n_cpu = 2) #> Call:admix_test(samples = list(data1, data2, data3), admixMod = list(admixMod1,  #>     admixMod2, admixMod3), test_method = "icv", conf_level = 0.95,  #>     n_sim_tab = 4, tune_penalty = FALSE, parallel = FALSE, n_cpu = 2) #>  #> Is the null hypothesis H0 rejected? what: Equality test of K unknown component distributions — IBM_k_samples_test
title: Equality test of K unknown component distributions — IBM_k_samples_test
text: Equality test unknown component distributions coming K (K > 1) admixture models, based Inversion - Best Matching (IBM) approach. Recall K populations following admixture models, one probability density functions (pdf) l_k = p_k*f_k + (1-p_k)*g_k, g_k known pdf l_k corresponds observed sample. Perform following hypothesis test: H0 : f_1 = ... = f_K   H1 : f_i differs f_j (different j, ,j 1,...,K).

title: Equality test of K unknown component distributions — IBM_k_samples_test
code: IBM_k_samples_test(   samples,   admixMod,   conf_level = 0.95,   sim_U = NULL,   tune_penalty = TRUE,   n_sim_tab = 100,   parallel = FALSE,   n_cpu = 2 )

title: Equality test of K unknown component distributions — IBM_k_samples_test
text: samples list K samples studied, following admixture distributions. admixMod list objects class class admix_model, containing useful information distributions parameters. conf_level confidence level K-sample test. sim_U (default NULL) Random draws inner convergence part contrast defined IBM approach (see 'Details' ). tune_penalty (default TRUE) boolean allows choose classical penalty term optimized penalty (embedding tuning parameters, automatically optimized). Optimized penalty particularly useful low unbalanced sample sizes detect alternatives null hypothesis (H0). recommended set TRUE. n_sim_tab (default 100) Number simulated Gaussian processes tabulating inner convergence distribution 'icv' testing method using IBM estimation approach. parallel (default FALSE) Boolean indicate whether parallel computations performed (speed-tabulation). n_cpu (default 2) Number cores used paralleling computations.

title: Equality test of K unknown component distributions — IBM_k_samples_test
text: object class admix_test, containing 17 attributes: 1) number samples test; 2) sizes sample; 3) information component distributions sample; 4) reject decision test; 5) confidence level test (1-alpha, alpha refers first-type error); 6) test p-value; 7) 95th-percentile contrast tabulated distribution; 8) test statistic value; 9) selected rank (number terms involved test statistic); 10) terms (pairwise contrasts) involved test statistic; 11) boolean indicating whether penalization corresponds null hypothesis considered; 12) value penalized test statistics; 13) selected optimal 'gamma' parameter (see reference ); 14) selected optimal constant involved penalization process (see also reference); 15) tabulated distribution contrast; 16) estimated mixing proportions (implemented yet, since makes sense case equal unknown component distributions); 17) matrix pairwise contrasts (distance two samples).

No #> p-value of the test: 0.571 # }

text: Create clusters unknown components related K populations following admixture models. Based K-sample test using Inversion - Best Matching (IBM) approach, see 'Details' information.

title: Clustering of K populations following admixture models — admix_cluster
code: admix_cluster(   samples,   admixMod,   conf_level = 0.95,   tune_penalty = TRUE,   tabul_dist = NULL,   echo = TRUE,   ... )

title: Clustering of K populations following admixture models — admix_cluster
text: samples list K (K>1) samples studied, following admixture distributions. admixMod list objects class admix_model, containing useful information distributions parameters. conf_level (default 0.95) confidence level k-sample tests used clustering procedure. tune_penalty (default TRUE) boolean allows choose classical penalty term optimized penalty (embedding tuning parameters, automatically optimized). Optimized penalty particularly useful low/mid-sized samples, unbalanced sample sizes detect alternatives null hypothesis (H0). recommended use . tabul_dist (default NULL) useful comparisons detected clusters different confidence levels. list tabulated distributions stochastic integral used k-sample test, element cluster previously detected. echo (default TRUE) Display remaining computation time. ... Optional arguments IBM_k_samples_test; namely 'n_sim_tab', 'parallel' 'n_cpu'. crucial speed-building clusters.

title: Clustering of K populations following admixture models — admix_cluster
text: object class admix_cluster, containing 12 attributes: 1) number samples study; 2) sizes samples; 3) information mixture components sample (distributions parameters); 4) number detected clusters; 5) list p-values k-sample test origin detected clusters; 6) cluster affiliation sample; 7) confidence level statistical tests; 8) samples cluster; 9) size clusters; 10) estimated weights unknown component distributions inside cluster (remind estimated weights consistent unknown components tested identical, case inside clusters); 11) matrix pairwise discrepancies across samples; 12) list tabulated distributions used statistical tests involved building clusters.

title: Clustering of K populations following admixture models — admix_cluster
code: # \donttest{ ## Simulate mixture data: mixt1 <- twoComp_mixt(n = 2600, weight = 0.8,                       comp.dist = list("gamma", "exp"),                       comp.param = list(list("shape" = 16, "scale" = 1/4),                                         list("rate" = 1/3.5))) mixt2 <- twoComp_mixt(n = 3000, weight = 0.7,                       comp.dist = list("gamma", "exp"),                       comp.param = list(list("shape" = 14, "scale" = 1/2),                                         list("rate" = 1/5))) mixt3 <- twoComp_mixt(n = 3500, weight = 0.6,                       comp.dist = list("gamma", "gamma"),                       comp.param = list(list("shape" = 16, "scale" = 1/4),                                         list("shape" = 12, "scale" = 1/2))) mixt4 <- twoComp_mixt(n = 4800, weight = 0.5,                       comp.dist = list("gamma", "exp"),                       comp.param = list(list("shape" = 14, "scale" = 1/2),                                         list("rate" = 1/7))) data1 <- getmixtData(mixt1) data2 <- getmixtData(mixt2) data3 <- getmixtData(mixt3) data4 <- getmixtData(mixt4) ## Define the admixture models: admixMod1 <- admix_model(knownComp_dist = mixt1$comp.dist[[2]],                          knownComp_param = mixt1$comp.param[[2]]) admixMod2 <- admix_model(knownComp_dist = mixt2$comp.dist[[2]],                          knownComp_param = mixt2$comp.param[[2]]) admixMod3 <- admix_model(knownComp_dist = mixt3$comp.dist[[2]],                          knownComp_param = mixt3$comp.param[[2]]) admixMod4 <- admix_model(knownComp_dist = mixt4$comp.dist[[2]],                          knownComp_param = mixt4$comp.param[[2]]) ## Clustering procedure: admix_cluster(samples = list(data1, data2, data3, data4),               admixMod = list(admixMod1, admixMod2, admixMod3, admixMod4),               conf_level = 0.95, tune_penalty = TRUE, n_sim_tab = 30) #>    |                                                           |                                                  |   0%   |                                                           |======                                            |  12%   |                                                           |======================================            |  75%   |                                                           |==================================================| 100% #> Call: #> admix_cluster(samples = list(data1, data2, data3, data4), admixMod = list(admixMod1,  #>     admixMod2, admixMod3, admixMod4), conf_level = 0.95, tune_penalty = TRUE,  #>     n_sim_tab = 30) #>  #> Number of detected clusters across the samples provided: 2. #>  #> List of samples involved in each built cluster (inside c()) : #>   - Cluster #1: samples c(2, 4) #>   - Cluster #2: samples c(1, 3) # }

what: Estimate the unknown parameters of the admixture model(s) — admix_estim
title: Estimate the unknown parameters of the admixture model(s) — admix_estim
text: Estimate component weights, location shift parameter (case symmetric unknown component density), unknown component distribution using different estimation techniques. remind -th admixture model probability density function (pdf) l_i : l_i = p_i * f_i + (1-p_i) * g_i, g_i known component density. unknown quantities p_i f_i estimated.

title: Estimate the unknown parameters of the admixture model(s) — admix_estim
code: admix_estim(samples, admixMod, est_method = c("PS", "BVdk", "IBM"), ...)

title: Estimate the unknown parameters of the admixture model(s) — admix_estim
text: samples list K (K>0) samples studied, following admixture distributions. admixMod list objects class admix_model, containing useful information distributions parameters. est_method estimation method applied. Can one 'BVdk' (Bordes Vandekerkhove estimator), 'PS' (Patra Sen estimator), 'IBM' (Inversion Best-Matching approach) continuous case (continuous random variable). 'IBM' discrete random variables. estimation method performed sample several samples provided. ... Optional arguments estim_PS, estim_BVdk estim_IBM depending choice made user estimation method.

title: Estimate the unknown parameters of the admixture model(s) — admix_estim
text: object class admix_estim, containing least 5 attributes: 1) number samples study; 2) information mixture components (distributions parameters); 3) sizes samples; 4) chosen estimation technique (one 'BVdk', 'PS' 'IBM'); 5) estimated mixing proportions (weights unknown component distributions mixture model). case 'BVdk' estimation, one additional attribute corresponding estimated location shift parameter included.

title: Estimate the unknown parameters of the admixture model(s) — admix_estim
text: details different estimation techniques, see references ) Patra Sen estimator ; ii) Bordes Vandekerkhove estimator ; iii) Inversion Best-Matching approach. Important note: estimation 'IBM' requires least two samples hand, provides unbiased estimators distributions unknown components equal (meaning requires perform previously test pairs samples, see ?admix_test).

title: Estimate the unknown parameters of the admixture model(s) — admix_estim
text: PatraSen2016admix BordesDelmasVandekerkhove2006admix BordesVandekerkhove2010admix MilhaudPommeretSalhiVandekerkhove2024aadmix

title: Estimate the unknown parameters of the admixture model(s) — admix_estim
text: Xavier Milhaud xavier.milhaud.research@gmail.com

title: Estimate the unknown parameters of the admixture model(s) — admix_estim
code: ## Simulate mixture data: mixt1 <- twoComp_mixt(n = 300, weight = 0.7,                       comp.dist = list("norm", "norm"),                       comp.param = list(list("mean" = -2, "sd" = 0.5),                                         list("mean" = 0, "sd" = 1))) mixt2 <- twoComp_mixt(n = 250, weight = 0.85,                       comp.dist = list("norm", "exp"),                       comp.param = list(list("mean" = -2, "sd" = 0.5),                                         list("rate" = 1))) data1 <- getmixtData(mixt1) data2 <- getmixtData(mixt2) ## Define the admixture models: admixMod1 <- admix_model(knownComp_dist = mixt1$comp.dist[[2]],                          knownComp_param = mixt1$comp.param[[2]]) admixMod2 <- admix_model(knownComp_dist = mixt2$comp.dist[[2]],                          knownComp_param = mixt2$comp.param[[2]]) # Estimation by different methods: admix_estim(samples=list(data1), admixMod=list(admixMod1), est_method = "BVdk") #> Warning: Estimation by 'BVdk' assumes the unknown component distribution #>   to have a symmetric probability density function. #> Call: #> admix_estim(samples = list(data1), admixMod = list(admixMod1),  #>     est_method = "BVdk") #>  #> Estimated weight of the unknown distribution in Sample 1: 0.65 #> Estimated location of the unknown distribution in Sample 1: -2.06 admix_estim(samples=list(data1,data2), admixMod=list(admixMod1,admixMod2), est_method = "PS") #> Call: #> admix_estim(samples = list(data1, data2), admixMod = list(admixMod1,  #>     admixMod2), est_method = "PS") #>  #> Estimated weight of the unknown distribution in Sample 1: 0.62 #> Estimated weight of the unknown distribution in Sample 2: 0.85 admix_estim(samples=list(data1,data2), admixMod=list(admixMod1,admixMod2), est_method = "IBM") #> Warning:  IBM estimators of two unknown proportions are reliable only if the two #>     corresponding unknown component distributions have been tested equal (see 'admix_test()'). #>     Furthermore, when both the known and unknown component distributions of the mixture #>     models are identical, the IBM approach provides an estimation of the ratio of the #>     actual mixing weights rather than an estimation of the unknown weights themselves. #> Call: #> admix_estim(samples = list(data1, data2), admixMod = list(admixMod1,  #>     admixMod2), est_method = "IBM") #>  #> Pairwise estimation performed (IBM estimation method).  #> N.B.: estimated weights are reliable only if the unknown #> component distributions have previously been tested equal. #> See ?admix_test.  #>  #> ----- Pair 1 and 2 ----- #> Estimated weight of the unknown distribution in Sample 1: 0.78 #> Estimated weight of the unknown distribution in Sample 2: 0.96

what: Equality test for the unknown components of admixture models — admix_test
title: Equality test for the unknown components of admixture models — admix_test
text: Perform hypothesis test unknown components list admixture models, remind -th admixture model probability density function (pdf) l_i : l_i = p_i * f_i + (1-p_i) * g_i, g_i known component density. unknown quantities p_i f_i thus estimated, leading test given following null alternative hypothesis: H0: f_i = f_j != j   H1 : exists least != j f_i differs f_j. test can performed using two methods, either comparison coefficients obtained polynomial basis expansions component densities, inner-convergence property obtained using IBM approach. See 'Details' information.

title: Equality test for the unknown components of admixture models — admix_test
code: admix_test(   samples,   admixMod,   test_method = c("poly", "icv"),   conf_level = 0.95,   ... )

title: Equality test for the unknown components of admixture models — admix_test
text: samples list K (K > 0) samples studied, one assumed follow mixture distribution. admixMod list objects class admix_model, containing useful information distributions parameters contamination / admixture models study. test_method testing method applied. Can either 'poly' (polynomial basis expansion) 'icv' (inner convergence IBM). testing method performed samples. one-sample case, 'Poly' available test gaussianity test. details, see section 'Details' . conf_level confidence level K-sample test. ... Depending choice made user test method ('poly' 'icv'), optional arguments gaussianity_test orthobasis_test (case 'poly'), IBM_k_samples_test case 'icv'. .

title: Equality test for the unknown components of admixture models — admix_test
text: object class admix_test, containing 8 attributes: 1) test decision (reject null hypothesis ); 2) p-value test; 3) confidence level test (1-alpha, alpha denotes level test equivalently type-error); 4) value test statistic; 5) number samples study; 6) respective size sample; 7) information mixture components (distributions parameters); 8) chosen testing method (either based polynomial basis expansions, inner convergence property; see given references).

title: Equality test for the unknown components of admixture models — admix_test
text: details implemented hypothesis tests, see references hereafter. .

text: Xavier Milhaud xavier.milhaud.research@gmail.com

title: Equality test for the unknown components of admixture models — admix_test
code: ####### Example with 2 samples mixt1 <- twoComp_mixt(n = 380, weight = 0.7,                       comp.dist = list("norm", "norm"),                       comp.param = list(list("mean" = -2, "sd" = 0.5),                                         list("mean" = 0, "sd" = 1))) mixt2 <- twoComp_mixt(n = 350, weight = 0.85,                       comp.dist = list("norm", "norm"),                       comp.param = list(list("mean" = -2, "sd" = 0.5),                                         list("mean" = -1, "sd" = 1))) data1 <- getmixtData(mixt1) data2 <- getmixtData(mixt2) admixMod1 <- admix_model(knownComp_dist = mixt1$comp.dist[[2]],                          knownComp_param = mixt1$comp.param[[2]]) admixMod2 <- admix_model(knownComp_dist = mixt2$comp.dist[[2]],                          knownComp_param = mixt2$comp.param[[2]]) admix_test(samples = list(data1,data2), admixMod = list(admixMod1,admixMod2),            conf_level = 0.95, test_method = "poly", ask_poly_param = FALSE, support = "Real") #>   Testing using polynomial basis expansions requires in theory a square-root n consistent estimation #>   of the proportions of the unknown component distributions (thus using 'BVdk' estimation by default, associated to unknown #>   component distributions with symmetric densities). However, it is allowed to use 'PS' estimation in practice (argument 'est_method' #>   has therefore to be set to 'PS'. In this case, the variance of estimators is obtained by boostrapping. #> Call:admix_test(samples = list(data1, data2), admixMod = list(admixMod1,  #>     admixMod2), test_method = "poly", conf_level = 0.95, ask_poly_param = FALSE,  #>     support = "Real") #>  #> Is the null hypothesis H0 rejected? No #> p-value of the test: 0.499

what: Estimates the decontaminated CDF of the unknown component in an admixture — decontaminated_cdf
title: Estimates the decontaminated CDF of the unknown component in an admixture — decontaminated_cdf
text: Estimates decontaminated cumulative distribution function (CDF) unknown component admixture model, using inversion admixture CDF. Recall admixture model follows cumulative distribution function (CDF) L, L = p*F + (1-p)*G, g known CDF p f unknown quantities.

title: Estimates the decontaminated CDF of the unknown component in an admixture — decontaminated_cdf
code: decontaminated_cdf(sample1, estim.p, admixMod)

title: Estimates the decontaminated CDF of the unknown component in an admixture — decontaminated_cdf
text: sample1 Observations sample study. estim.p estimated weight unknown component distribution, related proportion unknown component admixture model studied. admixMod object class 'admix_model', containing useful information distributions parameters.

title: Estimates the decontaminated CDF of the unknown component in an admixture — decontaminated_cdf
text: decontaminated CDF F admixture model, class 'stepfun' (step function).

title: Estimates the decontaminated CDF of the unknown component in an admixture — decontaminated_cdf
text: decontaminated CDF obtained inverting admixture CDF, given L = p*F + (1-p)*G, isolate unknown component F estimated p. means F = (1/hat(p)) * (hat(L)-(1-p)*G).

title: Estimates the decontaminated CDF of the unknown component in an admixture — decontaminated_cdf
text: Xavier Milhaud xavier.milhaud.research@gmail.com

title: Estimates the decontaminated CDF of the unknown component in an admixture — decontaminated_cdf
code: ## Simulate mixture data: mixt1 <- twoComp_mixt(n = 400, weight = 0.4,                       comp.dist = list("norm", "norm"),                       comp.param = list(list("mean" = 3, "sd" = 0.5),                                         list("mean" = 0, "sd" = 1))) mixt2 <- twoComp_mixt(n = 300, weight = 0.6,                       comp.dist = list("norm", "norm"),                       comp.param = list(list("mean" = 3, "sd" = 0.5),                                         list("mean" = 5, "sd" = 2))) data1 <- getmixtData(mixt1) data2 <- getmixtData(mixt2) ## Define the admixture models: admixMod1 <- admix_model(knownComp_dist = mixt1$comp.dist[[2]],                          knownComp_param = mixt1$comp.param[[2]]) admixMod2 <- admix_model(knownComp_dist = mixt2$comp.dist[[2]],                          knownComp_param = mixt2$comp.param[[2]]) ## Estimation: est <- admix_estim(samples = list(data1,data2),                    admixMod = list(admixMod1,admixMod2), est_method = 'PS') prop <- getmixingWeight(est) ## Determine the decontaminated version of the unknown CDF by inversion: F1 <- decontaminated_cdf(sample1 = data1, estim.p = prop[1], admixMod = admixMod1) F2 <- decontaminated_cdf(sample1 = data2, estim.p = prop[2], admixMod = admixMod2) abs <- seq(from=-1, to=4, length.out=100) plot(x=abs, y=F1(abs), xlim=c(-1,4), ylim=c(0,1), type="l") par(new = TRUE) plot(x=abs, y=F2(abs), xlim=c(-1,4), ylim=c(0,1), type="l", col="red")

title: Estimates the decontaminated density of the unknown component in an admixture — decontaminated_density
text: Xavier Milhaud xavier.milhaud.research@gmail.com

title: Estimates the decontaminated density of the unknown component in an admixture — decontaminated_density
code: ## Simulate mixture data: mixt1 <- twoComp_mixt(n = 400, weight = 0.4,                       comp.dist = list("norm", "norm"),                       comp.param = list(list("mean" = -2, "sd" = 0.5),                                         list("mean" = 0, "sd" = 1))) data1 <- getmixtData(mixt1) ## Define the admixture models: admixMod1 <- admix_model(knownComp_dist = mixt1$comp.dist[[2]],                          knownComp_param = mixt1$comp.param[[2]]) ## Estimation: est <- admix_estim(samples = list(data1), admixMod = list(admixMod1),                    est_method = 'PS') ## Determine the decontaminated version of the unknown density by inversion: decontaminated_density(sample1 = data1, estim.p = est$estimated_mixing_weights[1],                        admixMod = admixMod1) #> Call:decontaminated_density(sample1 = data1, estim.p = est$estimated_mixing_weights[1],  #>     admixMod = admixMod1) #>  #> function (x)  #> (1/estim.p) * (l1_emp(x) - (1 - estim.p) * g1(x)) #> <bytecode: 0x555b0f66f2b0> #> <environment: 0x555b0f66c168> #>  #> Type of support: Continuous  ####### Discrete support: mixt1 <- twoComp_mixt(n = 5000, weight = 0.6,                       comp.dist = list("pois", "pois"),                       comp.param = list(list("lambda" = 3),                                         list("lambda" = 2))) mixt2 <- twoComp_mixt(n = 4000, weight = 0.8,                       comp.dist = list("pois", "pois"),                       comp.param = list(list("lambda" = 3),                                         list("lambda" = 4))) data1 <- getmixtData(mixt1) data2 <- getmixtData(mixt2) ## Define the admixture models: admixMod1 <- admix_model(knownComp_dist = mixt1$comp.dist[[2]],                          knownComp_param = mixt1$comp.param[[2]]) admixMod2 <- admix_model(knownComp_dist = mixt2$comp.dist[[2]],                          knownComp_param = mixt2$comp.param[[2]]) ## Estimation: est <- admix_estim(samples = list(data1, data2),                    admixMod = list(admixMod1, admixMod2), est_method = 'IBM') #> Warning:  IBM estimators of two unknown proportions are reliable only if the two #>     corresponding unknown component distributions have been tested equal (see 'admix_test()'). #>     Furthermore, when both the known and unknown component distributions of the mixture #>     models are identical, the IBM approach provides an estimation of the ratio of the #>     actual mixing weights rather than an estimation of the unknown weights themselves. ## Determine the decontaminated version of the unknown density by inversion: decontaminated_density(sample1 = data1, estim.p = est$estimated_mixing_weights[1],                        admixMod = admixMod1) #> Call:decontaminated_density(sample1 = data1, estim.p = est$estimated_mixing_weights[1],  #>     admixMod = admixMod1) #>  #> function (x)  #> (1/estim.p) * (l1_emp(x) - (1 - estim.p) * g1(x)) #> <bytecode: 0x555b0f66f2b0> #> <environment: 0x555b14f40aa8> #>  #> Type of support: Discrete  ####### Finite discrete support: mixt1 <- twoComp_mixt(n = 12000, weight = 0.6,                       comp.dist = list("multinom", "multinom"),                       comp.param = list(list("size" = 1, "prob" = c(0.3,0.4,0.3)),                                         list("size" = 1, "prob" = c(0.6,0.3,0.1)))) mixt2 <- twoComp_mixt(n = 10000, weight = 0.8,                       comp.dist = list("multinom", "multinom"),                       comp.param = list(list("size" = 1, "prob" = c(0.3,0.4,0.3)),                                         list("size" = 1, "prob" = c(0.2,0.6,0.2)))) data1 <- getmixtData(mixt1) data2 <- getmixtData(mixt2) ## Define the admixture models: admixMod1 <- admix_model(knownComp_dist = mixt1$comp.dist[[2]],                          knownComp_param = mixt1$comp.param[[2]]) admixMod2 <- admix_model(knownComp_dist = mixt2$comp.dist[[2]],                          knownComp_param = mixt2$comp.param[[2]]) ## Estimation: est <- admix_estim(samples = list(data1, data2),                    admixMod = list(admixMod1, admixMod2), est_method = 'IBM') #> Warning:  IBM estimators of two unknown proportions are reliable only if the two #>     corresponding unknown component distributions have been tested equal (see 'admix_test()'). #>     Furthermore, when both the known and unknown component distributions of the mixture #>     models are identical, the IBM approach provides an estimation of the ratio of the #>     actual mixing weights rather than an estimation of the unknown weights themselves. ## Determine the decontaminated version of the unknown density by inversion: decontaminated_density(sample1 = data1, estim.p = est$estimated_mixing_weights[1],                        admixMod = admixMod1) #> Call:decontaminated_density(sample1 = data1, estim.p = est$estimated_mixing_weights[1],  #>     admixMod = admixMod1) #>  #> function (x)  #> (1/estim.p) * (l1_emp(x) - (1 - estim.p) * g1(x)) #> <bytecode: 0x555b0f66f2b0> #> <environment: 0x555b15b12250> #>  #> Type of support: Discrete

what: Estimation of the admixture parameters by Bordes & Vandekerkhove (2010) — estim_BVdk
title: Estimation of the admixture parameters by Bordes & Vandekerkhove (2010) — estim_BVdk
text: Estimates parameters admixture model unknown component assumed symmetric density. precisely, estimates two parameters (mixture weight location shift) admixture model pdf: l(x) = p*f(x-mu) + (1-p)*g(x), x R, g known component, p proportion f unknown component symmetric density. localization shift parameter denoted mu, component weight p. See reference details.

title: Estimation of the admixture parameters by Bordes & Vandekerkhove (2010) — estim_BVdk
code: estim_BVdk(   samples,   admixMod,   method = c("L-BFGS-B", "Nelder-Mead"),   compute_var = FALSE )

title: Estimation of the admixture parameters by Bordes & Vandekerkhove (2010) — estim_BVdk
text: samples observed sample study. admixMod object class admix_model, containing useful information distributions parameters. method method used throughout optimization process, either 'L-BFGS-B' 'Nelder-Mead' (see ?optim). compute_var (default FALSE) boolean indicates whether one computes variance estimators unknown mixing proportions location shift parameter.

title: Estimation of the admixture parameters by Bordes & Vandekerkhove (2010) — estim_BVdk
text: object class estim_BVdk, containing 8 attributes: 1) number sample study (set 1 ); 2) sample size; 3) information mixture components (distributions parameters); 4) estimation method (Bordes Vandekerkhove , see given reference); 5) estimated mixing proportion (weight unknown component distribution); 6) estimated location parameter unknown component distribution (symetric density); 7) variance two estimators (respectively mixing proportion location shift); 8) optimization method used.

title: Estimation of the admixture parameters by Bordes & Vandekerkhove (2010) — estim_BVdk
code: ## Simulate mixture data: mixt1 <- twoComp_mixt(n = 200, weight = 0.4,                       comp.dist = list("norm", "norm"),                       comp.param = list(list("mean" = -2, "sd" = 0.5),                                         list("mean" = 0, "sd" = 1))) ## Retrieves the mixture data: data1 <- getmixtData(mixt1) ## Define the admixture model: admixMod <- admix_model(knownComp_dist = mixt1$comp.dist[[2]],                         knownComp_param = mixt1$comp.param[[2]]) ## Perform the estimation of parameters in real-life: estim_BVdk(samples = data1, admixMod = admixMod, method = 'L-BFGS-B') #> Warning: Estimation by 'BVdk' assumes the unknown component distribution #>   to have a symmetric probability density function. #>  #> Call:estim_BVdk(samples = data1, admixMod = admixMod, method = "L-BFGS-B") #>  #> Estimated mixing proportion:  0.3997622  #> Estimated location parameter:  -1.986474  #> Variance of the mixing proportion estimator:  NA  #> Variance of the location shift estimator:  NA  #>   ## Second example: mixt2 <- twoComp_mixt(n = 200, weight = 0.65,                       comp.dist = list("norm", "exp"),                       comp.param = list(list("mean" = -1, "sd" = 0.5),                                         list("rate" = 1))) data2 <- getmixtData(mixt2) admixMod2 <- admix_model(knownComp_dist = mixt2$comp.dist[[2]],                         knownComp_param = mixt2$comp.param[[2]]) ## Perform the estimation of parameters in real-life: estim_BVdk(samples = data2, admixMod = admixMod2, method = 'L-BFGS-B',            compute_var = TRUE) #> Warning: Estimation by 'BVdk' assumes the unknown component distribution #>   to have a symmetric probability density function. #>  #> Call:estim_BVdk(samples = data2, admixMod = admixMod2, method = "L-BFGS-B",  #>     compute_var = TRUE) #>  #> Estimated mixing proportion:  0.6165552  #> Estimated location parameter:  -1.06661  #> Variance of the mixing proportion estimator:  0.001413177  #> Variance of the location shift estimator:  0.002412356  #>

title: Estimates weights of unknown components from 2 admixtures using IBM — estim_IBM

title: Estimates weights of unknown components from 2 admixtures using IBM — estim_IBM
code: ## Continuous support: simulate mixture data. mixt1 <- twoComp_mixt(n = 1500, weight = 0.5,                       comp.dist = list("norm", "norm"),                       comp.param = list(list("mean" = 3, "sd" = 0.5),                                         list("mean" = 0, "sd" = 1))) data1 <- getmixtData(mixt1) mixt2 <- twoComp_mixt(n = 2000, weight = 0.7,                       comp.dist = list("norm", "norm"),                       comp.param = list(list("mean" = 3, "sd" = 0.5),                                         list("mean" = 5, "sd" = 2))) data2 <- getmixtData(mixt2) ## Define the admixture models: admixMod1 <- admix_model(knownComp_dist = mixt1$comp.dist[[2]],                          knownComp_param = mixt1$comp.param[[2]]) admixMod2 <- admix_model(knownComp_dist = mixt2$comp.dist[[2]],                          knownComp_param = mixt2$comp.param[[2]]) ## Estimate the mixture weights of the two admixture models (provide only hat(theta)_n): estim_IBM(samples = list(data1,data2),           admixMod = list(admixMod1,admixMod2), n.integ = 1000) #> Warning:  IBM estimators of two unknown proportions are reliable only if the two #>     corresponding unknown component distributions have been tested equal (see 'admix_test()'). #>     Furthermore, when both the known and unknown component distributions of the mixture #>     models are identical, the IBM approach provides an estimation of the ratio of the #>     actual mixing weights rather than an estimation of the unknown weights themselves. #> Call:estim_IBM(samples = list(data1, data2), admixMod = list(admixMod1,  #>     admixMod2), n.integ = 1000) #>  #> Estimated weight of the unknown distribution in the 1st sample:  0.511  #> Estimated weight of the unknown distribution in the 2nd sample:  0.711  #> Estimated variance of the latter weight in the 1st sample:  NA  #> Estimated variance of the latter weight in the 2nd sample:  NA  #>   ## Example 2: multinomial distribution (discrete case). mixt1 <- twoComp_mixt(n = 1500, weight = 0.8,                       comp.dist = list("multinom", "multinom"),                       comp.param = list(list("size" = 1, "prob" = c(0.2,0.3,0.5)),                                         list("size" = 1, "prob" = c(0.1,0.6,0.3)))) data1 <- getmixtData(mixt1) mixt2 <- twoComp_mixt(n = 2000, weight = 0.3,                       comp.dist = list("multinom", "multinom"),                       comp.param = list(list("size" = 1, "prob" = c(0.2,0.3,0.5)),                                         list("size" = 1, "prob" = c(0.7,0.1,0.2)))) data2 <- getmixtData(mixt2) ## Define the admixture models: admixMod1 <- admix_model(knownComp_dist = mixt1$comp.dist[[2]],                          knownComp_param = mixt1$comp.param[[2]]) admixMod2 <- admix_model(knownComp_dist = mixt2$comp.dist[[2]],                          knownComp_param = mixt2$comp.param[[2]]) ## Estimate the mixture weights of the two admixture models (provide only hat(theta)_n): estim_IBM(samples = list(data1,data2), admixMod = list(admixMod1,admixMod2),           compute_var = TRUE) #> Warning:  IBM estimators of two unknown proportions are reliable only if the two #>     corresponding unknown component distributions have been tested equal (see 'admix_test()'). #>     Furthermore, when both the known and unknown component distributions of the mixture #>     models are identical, the IBM approach provides an estimation of the ratio of the #>     actual mixing weights rather than an estimation of the unknown weights themselves. #> Call:estim_IBM(samples = list(data1, data2), admixMod = list(admixMod1,  #>     admixMod2), compute_var = TRUE) #>  #> Estimated weight of the unknown distribution in the 1st sample:  0.719  #> Estimated weight of the unknown distribution in the 2nd sample:  0.306  #> Estimated variance of the latter weight in the 1st sample:  0.005797  #> Estimated variance of the latter weight in the 2nd sample:  0.000551  #>

title: Estimates in an admixture using Patra and Sen approach — estim_PS
text: Estimation weight distribution unknown component admixture model, Patra Sen approach. Remind admixture probability density function (pdf) l given l = p*f + (1-p)*g, g known component two-component mixture, p unknown proportion unknown component distribution f. information 'Details' concerning estimation method.

title: Estimates in an admixture using Patra and Sen approach — estim_PS
text: samples Sample studied. admixMod object class admix_model, containing information known component distribution parameter(s). method One 'lwr.bnd', fixed' 'cv': depending whether compute lower bound mixing proportion, estimate based value 'c.n' use cross-validation choosing 'c.n' (tuning parameter). c.n (default NULL) positive number penalization, see reference . NULL, equals 0.1*log(log(n)). folds (optional, default 10) Number folds used cross-validation. reps (optional, default 1) Number replications cross-validation. cn.s (optional) sequence 'c.n' used cross-validation (vector values). Default equally spaced grid 100 values .001 x log(log(n)) 0.2 x log(log(n)). cn.length (optional, default 100) Number equally spaced tuning parameter (.001 x log(log(n)) 0.2 x log(log(n))). Values search . gridsize (default 600) Number equally spaced points (0 1) evaluate distance function. Larger values computationally intensive also lead accurate estimates.

title: Estimates in an admixture using Patra and Sen approach — estim_PS

what: Gaussianity test in an admixture model — gaussianity_test
title: Gaussianity test in an admixture model — gaussianity_test
text: Performs hypothesis test check gaussianity unknown mixture component, given known component support real line. Recall admixture model probability density function (pdf) l = p*f + (1-p)*g, g known pdf l observed (others unknown). test requires optimization (estimate unknown parameters) defined Bordes & Vandekerkhove (2010), means unknown mixture component must symmetric density.

text: Tests null hypothesis (H0: f1=f2) using decomposition unknown component densities two admixture distributions adequate orthonormal polynomial basis. Recall two admixture models respective probability density functions (pdf) l1 = p1*f1 + (1-p1)g1 l2 = p2f2 + (1-p2)*g2, g1 g2 known elements l1 l2 observed. admixture weights p1 p2 thus estimated. information method, see 'Details' .

title: Plot method for class 'decontaminated_density' — plot.decontaminated_density
code: ####### Continuous support: ## Simulate mixture data: mixt1 <- twoComp_mixt(n = 400, weight = 0.4,                       comp.dist = list("norm", "norm"),                       comp.param = list(list("mean" = 3, "sd" = 0.5),                                         list("mean" = 0, "sd" = 1))) mixt2 <- twoComp_mixt(n = 350, weight = 0.6,                       comp.dist = list("norm", "norm"),                       comp.param = list(list("mean" = 3, "sd" = 0.5),                                         list("mean" = 5, "sd" = 2))) data1 <- getmixtData(mixt1) data2 <- getmixtData(mixt2) ## Define the admixture models: admixMod1 <- admix_model(knownComp_dist = mixt1$comp.dist[[2]],                          knownComp_param = mixt1$comp.param[[2]]) admixMod2 <- admix_model(knownComp_dist = mixt2$comp.dist[[2]],                          knownComp_param = mixt2$comp.param[[2]]) ## Estimation: est <- admix_estim(samples = list(data1,data2),                    admixMod = list(admixMod1,admixMod2), est_method = 'PS') prop <- getmixingWeight(est) ## Determine the decontaminated version of the unknown density by inversion: res1 <- decontaminated_density(sample1 = data1, estim.p = prop[1],                                admixMod = admixMod1) res2 <- decontaminated_density(sample1 = data2, estim.p = prop[2],                                admixMod = admixMod2) ## Use appropriate sequence of x values: plot(x = res1, x_val = seq(from = 0, to = 6, length.out = 100), add_plot = FALSE) plot(x = res2, col = "red", x_val = seq(from = 0, to = 6, length.out = 100), add_plot = TRUE)   ####### Countable discrete support: mixt1 <- twoComp_mixt(n = 4000, weight = 0.7,                       comp.dist = list("pois", "pois"),                       comp.param = list(list("lambda" = 3),                                         list("lambda" = 2))) mixt2 <- twoComp_mixt(n = 3500, weight = 0.85,                       comp.dist = list("pois", "pois"),                       comp.param = list(list("lambda" = 3),                                         list("lambda" = 4))) data1 <- getmixtData(mixt1) data2 <- getmixtData(mixt2) ## Define the admixture models: admixMod1 <- admix_model(knownComp_dist = mixt1$comp.dist[[2]],                          knownComp_param = mixt1$comp.param[[2]]) admixMod2 <- admix_model(knownComp_dist = mixt2$comp.dist[[2]],                          knownComp_param = mixt2$comp.param[[2]]) ## Estimation: est <- admix_estim(samples = list(data1,data2),                    admixMod = list(admixMod1,admixMod2), est_method = "IBM") #> Warning:  IBM estimators of two unknown proportions are reliable only if the two #>     corresponding unknown component distributions have been tested equal (see 'admix_test()'). #>     Furthermore, when both the known and unknown component distributions of the mixture #>     models are identical, the IBM approach provides an estimation of the ratio of the #>     actual mixing weights rather than an estimation of the unknown weights themselves. prop <- getmixingWeight(est) ## Determine the decontaminated version of the unknown density by inversion: res1 <- decontaminated_density(sample1 = data1, estim.p = prop[1],                                admixMod = admixMod1) res2 <- decontaminated_density(sample1 = data2, estim.p = prop[2],                                admixMod = admixMod2) ## Use appropriate sequence of x values: plot(x = res1, x_val = seq(from = 0, to = 15, by = 1), add_plot = FALSE) plot(x = res2, x_val = seq(from = 0, to = 15, by = 1), add_plot = TRUE, col = "red")   ####### Finite discrete support: mixt1 <- twoComp_mixt(n = 4000, weight = 0.7,                       comp.dist = list("multinom", "multinom"),                       comp.param = list(list("size" = 1, "prob" = c(0.3,0.4,0.3)),                                         list("size" = 1, "prob" = c(0.6,0.3,0.1)))) mixt2 <- twoComp_mixt(n = 3500, weight = 0.85,                       comp.dist = list("multinom", "multinom"),                       comp.param = list(list("size" = 1, "prob" = c(0.3,0.4,0.3)),                                         list("size" = 1, "prob" = c(0.2,0.6,0.2)))) data1 <- getmixtData(mixt1) data2 <- getmixtData(mixt2) ## Define the admixture models: admixMod1 <- admix_model(knownComp_dist = mixt1$comp.dist[[2]],                          knownComp_param = mixt1$comp.param[[2]]) admixMod2 <- admix_model(knownComp_dist = mixt2$comp.dist[[2]],                          knownComp_param = mixt2$comp.param[[2]]) ## Estimation: est <- admix_estim(samples = list(data1,data2),                    admixMod = list(admixMod1,admixMod2), est_method = "IBM") #> Warning:  IBM estimators of two unknown proportions are reliable only if the two #>     corresponding unknown component distributions have been tested equal (see 'admix_test()'). #>     Furthermore, when both the known and unknown component distributions of the mixture #>     models are identical, the IBM approach provides an estimation of the ratio of the #>     actual mixing weights rather than an estimation of the unknown weights themselves. prop <- getmixingWeight(est) ## Determine the decontaminated version of the unknown density by inversion: res1 <- decontaminated_density(sample1 = data1, estim.p = prop[1],                                admixMod = admixMod1) res2 <- decontaminated_density(sample1 = data2, estim.p = prop[2],                                admixMod = admixMod2) ## Use appropriate sequence of x values: plot(x = res1, x_val = seq(from=1, to=3, by=1), add_plot = FALSE) plot(x = res2, x_val = seq(from=1, to=3, by=1), add_plot = TRUE, col = "red")

title: Simulation of a two-component mixture model — twoComp_mixt
code: twoComp_mixt(   n = 1000,   weight = 0.5,   comp.dist = list("norm", "norm"),   comp.param = list(list(mean = 0, sd = 1), list(mean = 2, sd = 1)) )

title: Simulation of a two-component mixture model — twoComp_mixt
text: n Number observations simulated. weight Weight first component distribution (distribution f) mixture. comp.dist list two elements corresponding component distributions (specified R native names) involved mixture model. elements respectively refer two component distributions f g. comp.param list two elements corresponding parameters component distributions, element list . names used list must correspond native R argument names distributions. elements respectively refer parameters f g distributions mixture model.

title: Simulation of a two-component mixture model — twoComp_mixt
text: object class twoComp_mixt, containing eight attributes: 1) number simulated observations, 2) simulated mixture data, 3) support distributions, 4) name component distributions, 5) name parameters component distributions values, 6) mixing proportion, 7) observations coming first component, 8) observations coming second component.

title: Simulation of a two-component mixture model — twoComp_mixt
text: Xavier Milhaud xavier.milhaud.research@gmail.com

title: Simulation of a two-component mixture model — twoComp_mixt
code: ## Mixture of continuous random variables: sim.X <- twoComp_mixt(n = 2000, weight = 0.5,                       comp.dist = list("norm", "norm"),                       comp.param = list(list("mean"=3, "sd"=0.5),                                         list("mean"=0, "sd"=1))) sim.Y <- twoComp_mixt(n = 1200, weight = 0.7,                       comp.dist = list("norm", "exp"),                       comp.param = list(list("mean"=-3, "sd"=0.5),                                         list("rate"=1))) print(sim.X) #>  #> Call:twoComp_mixt(n = 2000, weight = 0.5, comp.dist = list("norm",  #>     "norm"), comp.param = list(list(mean = 3, sd = 0.5), list(mean = 0,  #>     sd = 1))) #>  #> Component distributions:  norm norm  #> Support of the component distributions:  Continuous Continuous  #>  #> Value of the component parameters:  #> mean   sd mean   sd  #>  3.0  0.5  0.0  1.0  #>  #> Mixing proportion: 0.5  #>  #> Number of observations:  2000  #>  #> Simulated data (first 10 obs.):  #>  2.93475 2.692277 0.6343698 3.718913 0.9463694 3.622782 2.175062 2.664207 -0.4500302 1.158445  #>  #> Simulated observations coming from the 1st component (first 10 obs.):  #>  2.93475 2.692277 3.718913 3.622782 2.175062 2.664207 3.03669 2.584259 3.011138 3.701056  #>  #> Simulated observations coming from the 2nd component (first 10 obs.):  #>  0.6343698 0.9463694 -0.4500302 1.158445 -0.09883099 0.4869106 -0.320834 0.2575842 0.1839459 -0.24402  #>  plot(sim.X, xlim=c(-5,5), ylim=c(0,0.5)) plot(sim.Y, add.plot = TRUE, xlim=c(-5,5), ylim=c(0,0.5), col = "red")   ## Mixture of discrete random variables: sim.X <- twoComp_mixt(n = 2000, weight = 0.5,                       comp.dist = list("multinom", "multinom"),                       comp.param = list(list("size"=1, "prob"=c(0.3,0.4,0.3)),                                         list("size"=1, "prob"=c(0.1,0.2,0.7)))) print(sim.X) #>  #> Call:twoComp_mixt(n = 2000, weight = 0.5, comp.dist = list("multinom",  #>     "multinom"), comp.param = list(list(size = 1, prob = c(0.3,  #>     0.4, 0.3)), list(size = 1, prob = c(0.1, 0.2, 0.7)))) #>  #> Component distributions:  multinom multinom  #> Support of the component distributions:  Discrete Discrete  #>  #> Value of the component parameters:  #>  size prob1 prob2 prob3  size prob1 prob2 prob3  #>   1.0   0.3   0.4   0.3   1.0   0.1   0.2   0.7  #>  #> Mixing proportion: 0.5  #>  #> Number of observations:  2000  #>  #> Obtained multinomial mixture distribution:  #>  401 599 1000  #>  plot(sim.X)
